This is the anime that changed my point of view about love-romace-slice of life anime types. I've watched the whole Kyoto Animation-Key-Visual Art's set: Air, Clannad, and this one. I'm reviewing this one because of all the other ones (that are masterpieces as well) I really think that Kanon has to be the best between them all, also this is one of my favourites and best animes of all time.
Now the story is something different from one's is used to watch, is actually the base of the success for this anime. The context of the plot is Visual Art's presentation card, they always attempt todevelop the story line the same way around: "a boy who returns to a place he had been before, a long time ago. He doesn't remember much about it, but as he interacts with the other characters (mostly females) he finds out that he had relations with those characters in the past and, in the end, remembers it all". Bassicaly the anime storyline is all about the importance of memories for a human being. It might sound a little to stupid but the way Visual Art's Key puts all the characters, locations and artistic material together is just so good that the story goes from stupid to a really serious and complex one and ends up being film-worthy. 


The pace of the story may seen slow at first but when the main events from each arc do take place the quantity of information from each one is so big to digest that it feels like the story has passed from one arc to another way too fast and, when you finally finish watching the anime, you just can't wait to watch it again because you thought you didn't get the whole story. There are some magical, supernatural conflicts in this anime, but they just have the right amount of credibility in them to be part of the slice of life theme in the anime. Also (including the said supernatural and magical themes) the story has the whole package: romance, drama, humor and some, really often, heartbreaking passages that will make sure you keep your tissue pack near you until the anime is over for good. 


The anime just looks perfect. The design of the characters and spaces are Kyoto Animation's and Key's masterwork. The city looks so colourful and real. From the buildings, to the outskirts houses, the school halls and the woods. So you could say that the city has it's own personality. The characters appereance is in a different level that most animes are. They are just so full of life, every movement is highly detailed and beautifully expressed, also the psychical aspects give each character it's own unique impression on the viewer. This is definitely a successfull formula that has worked in Air and Clannad, none other anime appeals artistically to me as much as this one does.  


From the opening song to each charater's voice acting the sound is just right. The songs used in this anime are all (as you can imagine) slow and sad but of course this matches perfectly the theme setting. The voice acting is very convincing and I love that the voices sound taken just from the streets, they sound like normal persons talking to each other and the voice acting has nothing to do with elaborate voices or appealing voices, just normal voices which express the emotions of the characters in a very realistic way. So the sound is not perfect but superior from most stardard animes.


Characters are the handling that connects the base and gives it stability. I have to say that the characters this anime offers are one of the most amazing I have ever seen. Everything is perfect about them from the looks to the unique personality of each one, no doubt this is a Kyoto Animation's and Key's work. Starting with exuberant hair colors and finishing with big lively eyes the characters look so original, so different from any other anime series that, after you watch this, all the other animes will look either bad or weird. The personality of each character is just a variety of what you would find if you walk around the streets and watch any one around (of course they have that "japaneese shy factor" if you know what I mean). I noticed that all the female leads (except Mai) have a characteristic weird sound in they're dialect (you know the Uguuuu!, Nyuuuu! or Auuuu!). This really does make the characters more different one from another, being this like a characteristic "spark" each one has, but at the same time it connects all of them creating a sort of invisible bond between them.


Well Here you have it: this is what a mix of a perfect story, art, characters, a great sound and a HUGE enjoyment factor gives as a result: a masterpiece. I didn't like this type of anime before I watched this. I always went to see the most gory and bloody anime I could find. So even if you think you don't like this kind of animes I advise you: watch this and try to say the same thing again after you had finished it. If you don't watch Kanon you are missing a unique experience in animation, a incomparable experience. The only problem I found is that, after finishing the anime, you will look down at any other anime of this type and always will compare it to this one and, for once, let's be real: there is almost nothing out there that you can compare with this anime, Kanon it's just in a whole different level.

"We don't remember days- we remember moments. The richness of life lies in memories we have forgotten" -Makoto Sawatari
I have never before felt so ambivalent about a show, or writing a review for one. Generally speaking, by the end of the show, my opinions on it have solidified, and it's fairly cut and dried whether I liked it, disliked it, or really couldn't care less one way or the other.
...Then I saw Kanon. 
There are so many things that Kanon gets right, and at the same time, many other things that it does wrong, and that I just have a very hard time forgiving. PerhapsI'm guilty of thinking about it too hard, but we shall see. 



Artwork and Animation: 7


When you mention Air or Kanon, sometimes people will look at you funny, like "You actually watched that Toei produced trash?", but this is the Kyoto Animation version. You can clarify which one you saw very easily by saying, "It's the one with the bug people", and everyone will instantly know. 


Yes, those enormous, compound eyed girls are back! They take front and center in Kanon. I even went into photoshop and took the area of Ayu's eyes divided by the area of her face, and 16.7% of her head is eyeball. 16.7%! 


Jokes aside, the artwork in Kanon is good. The show is nearly 10 years old, and it holds up well against modern productions, while retaining the signature Kyoto feel. Expect a lot of nice natural backdrops (in the snow, no less- an excellent Christmas break anime) and cityscape. The characters always maintain a great level of detail, and everything is fairly well polished. 



Sound and Voice Acting: 10


I'm going to be honest here; I think Kanon probably has one of, if not THE best written dialogues I've ever heard in an anime series. The outstanding performances of the totally aside, the writing is a star in its own right here. The dialogue, while cheesy when appropriate, actually feels like real people talking to each other, conversing, throwing snide comments at each other, being indignant, the emotional highs, crushing lows, and everything that the characters go through that comes out auditorily hits every bit of the mark. 


My hat is off to Chris Patton (Greed, FMA/B) for his portrayal of Yuichi. I don't think I've ever before identified with a character as much as Yuichi. Everything about the performance is fantastic. I don't mean this in a fan-rant kind of way, as this is my first exposure to Patton as a main character, but the nuance and feeling he put into the role is admirable. Yuichi really feels like that sarcastic, smart mouth friend. The delivery and timing of the jokes is impeccable as well- again, an excellently flowing dialogue that has few peers in the anime realm.


Brittney Karbowski appears as Ayu- and also does a great job portraying the immature little genki girl whose innocence and naïveté know no bounds. It's an endearing performance, for a little twit that started off as the annoying little sister character. 


Even Greg Ayres, as smoked out as he always sounds, showed out in a smaller supporting role. ADV did an outstanding job with both casting and direction of the performances.



Characters : 9


When I said above that I didn't think I'd ever seen a character that I identified with as much as I did with Yuichi, I mean that the character of Yuichi is almost a direct transplant of my own personality. Watching Kanon was almost like watching a show with a self-insert protagonist, and easily allowed me to empathize with Yuichi. 


Yuichi is that kind hearted jerk that you just can't help but like. He's always armed with a snappy comeback and sometimes takes his caustic jokes too far, but he always means well, even when mercilessly mocking his cousin Nayuki or friends. No one is safe from the snark, and Yuichi lets it fly. 


Despite his seemingly uncaring outward facade, deep inside, Yuichi is a very caring and devoted friend. The conflicts of the show revolve around the rough times that happen to him and his little group of friends, and each time, he's there for the affected party, and tries his best to be able to be sympathetic, but without being obsequious or fake. He's not a sycophantic slave boy to this collection of attractive girls he befriends; but rather a concerned and dependable brother type figure.


It goes without saying that the hero has to earn his happy ending (especially in a Key written Visual Novel, and Yuichi is put through a lot throughout the course of Kanon. 


As for the other characters in the show, there are stronger ones, and weaker ones. Each has their distinctive arc in the story, and far be it from me to spoil the results of any of them, but I found the ones with Shiori, Nayuki, and Ayu to be among the stronger ones. It also helped that they were stacked more at the end of the show than the beginning. 



Story: 5 


Again with firsts, I think this is the first show that I've assigned a near perfect score to characters, and a poor one to the story, but there's a very good reason for this, and my biggest gripe about Kanon in general. 


Magic. 


I understand that the show is based on the idea of "miracles can happen", and it's built on a cycle of character buildup, ensuing relationship, and then some kind of heartbreaking event for the characters involved. It's been used in an uncountable amount of media- some of the greatest films and literature pieces of all time use it to great effect, and it's one of the tried and true ways to make a heartfelt or tearjerker drama when done correctly. 


The only addition to this formula that Kanon makes is the addition of a supernatural element. 


Like, they could just swap out "this character isn't human and is dying because they can't maintain their human form" for "this character has an incurable, rare hereditary disease and is going to die" and it would work ABSOLUTELY perfectly without changing anything in the show- not even the dialogue. I just cannot for the life of me understand why it has to be a supernatural cause for the illnesses of the characters.


I hated this device in Air, and I hate it in Kanon. All they had to do was just make the characters have a scientific/medical reason for why they're ill and be done with it. It's realistic, it's tragic, and moreover, it might actually make me feel something. 


It's not as though the writers at Key (or even Kyoto, if they changed details somewhat) are ABOVE using the "incurable illness" as a plot device, either, because it appears in this show too!! And guess what? I actually felt something. I genuinely felt bad for the character, and you know what? The other characters in the show did too. To a much more believable degree than for the 'shapeshifting' character, certainly. 


I cannot feel ANYTHING for some spiritual being pretending to be a person that was never human to begin with. It completely removes the all-important HUMAN element. I don't even know that the character is capable of feeling human emotions/moods/or complex brain chemical reactions known as "love". 


-~-


Kanon is one of those shows that, on the surface, is very sweet- but falls apart pretty quickly once you start thinking about it. 


The next issue it has, and it's one I'm willing to overlook not only because it's so centric to the story, but because it's also one of the best parts, (but I feel it needs mention,) is an illusionary/wrong memory of a character. Another aspect of the conflict of the show is that Yuichi has lost his memories of his time spent in the city where all of this takes place, because the last time he was there 7 years ago, a traumatic event occurred, and as a result, he repressed his memories of his old friends and the times they had and spends the story recovering them.


I absolutely refuse to believe that EVERY person in the story went along with Yuichi's delusions of the existence of this character, for several reasons. 


There is physical evidence that this character exists, not to mention that other characters speak directly to this character. It's not like a movie where the main character believes that someone else is with them and performing the actions for them while they spectate, no, other characters besides the main character interact with this person. 


There cannot be two of this character, due to the fact that (for the sake of the ending of the arc) this character appears again (difficult to describe this point without spoilers). As Shiro Emiya once said: "People die when they're killed". Also, how Yuichi manages to find an item that was apparently not given to the character as he falsely and incorrectly remembered, yet other characters comment on this character having said item. 


There is no way anyone could go along with such an elaborate lie, unless (from an unseen perspective) Yuichi also acts out as the character he's hallucinating about, period. Yuichi explaining all the personality quirks and mannerisms of this illusory character in such an extreme detail to anyone who would have had any bearing on the story and "remembers" this character is just ludicrous to imagine. Again, this is where thinking about it too hard really causes Kanon to fall apart. 



Enjoyment and Overall: 7, 7


I can't hate Kanon- I actually really want to like it, because the main character is the anime incarnation of myself, and the plot has several sweet moments that were rather touching; but it's just so hard to overlook the screwy plot devices in the story. 


Kanon has, simultaneously, one of the best written comedy dialogues I've seen in an anime, and one of the absolute worst plot devices, ever. There are some beautiful moments and cute characters in it- I can see why it's held up as a classic heartwarming tale for the cold winter months. It definitely has an emotional appeal to it that a lesser show would have to kick two kittens and kill a lot of little moe girl characters to achieve, all while managing to be a cohesive, flowing tale. (adapting 5 routes of a VN in 24 episodes is no mean feat- especially considering Fate Stay Night is on pace for around 80 episodes for three.) 



Recommend? 


Yes. Where I disliked Air for the misuse of supernatural and a tangential, tacked on plot that goes nowhere, Kanon refines this and brings it back down to Earth. It's a much better paced, has much more interesting characters, and a sweet story that makes it easy to watch and hard to put down. 



Tl;dr


+ Great MC, especially for fans of the deadpan snarker

+ Outstanding dialogue and comedy writing; among the best


+/- Mixed story arc appeal- some are much weaker than others, especially as far as believability goes


- Misuse of "magic" when it could have easily been substituted out for legitimate scientific/medical reasons. 



Thanks for the read, feel free to drop me a comment when you feel that fanboy/girl rage building up- or say something nice.

"...It's a promise."
I remember, about a year ago, I watched Kanon 2006. It was good and all, but at the time, I just finished watching Clannad: After Story, which became my favorite anime ever (and still is). Because of that, all I did was compare Kanon to Clannad. And because of that I didn't like it very much. I soon forgot about Kanon, and whenever it was brought up in conversation, I always said, "Just watch Clannad. It's the same as Kanon, except 10 times better lolz."
...What an idiotic statement that is.
I recently rewatched Kanon, and decided not to compare it to Clannad at all.And what would you know, I ended up enjoying it. A lot. So much so, in fact, that I immediately put it in my favorites list here on MAL, and I don't see myself removing it anytime soon.

Why did I enjoy watching Kanon so much? Well, not comparing it to Clannad did help a little, but it honestly is just an amazing series.

Touching drama. Hilarious and adorable comedy. Heartwarming moments that made me cry. This anime has all of that. Not only all of that, though, but the cast of characters in Kanon are so lovable and wonderful, as well... I don't know where to start!

Well, let's get story out of the way, shall we?


~STORY~ The story in Kanon does start off pretty basic: Yuuichi Aizawa moves into a town that he hasn't visited for 7 years. He moves in with his cousin, Nayuki, and his aunt, Akiko. Throughout the series there are several arcs, focusing on each female character. This is the basic layout of quite a few visual novel anime adaptations, I will admit. Where the story truly shines though are the arcs that have to do with those female characters I briefly mentioned, and the relationships Yuuichi forms with each of them. And all of the arcs, literally all 5 or so of them, made me tear up. Some of them are truly sad and bittersweet, and the way they are presented is spectacular. They are all really quite original, as well. You won't see some of these stories in other slice of life anime. Some of the arcs are so original and farfetched, even, that some viewers might be thrown off by them. I personally didn't have any problem with it, as I kind of expect some supernatural stories in Key anime at this point. I really like them, actually.


~CHARACTERS~ As mentioned previously, the characters in Kanon are great. Especially at the time that the visual novel was made (1999), they were, and I'd claim that they still are, pretty original. Some, like Ayu, may seem like a typical cutesy moe character, and you'd be kinda right. But their stories are truly unique. I grew so attached to these characters. There are quite a lot, so I won't go into TOO much detail with all of them (however, I will talk about them, so stay tuned), but I feel like I should at least go into detail about Yuuichi and Ayu.


~ Yuuichi ~ He's the main character. I liked him so much because he is a sarcastic bastard who loves to mess around with the girls. His exchanges with some of the characters, like Ayu in particular, are hilarious. But you can just tell that he does care deeply for all of the characters... he truly does. You can feel all the pain and guilt that he feels. And then you can also LOL when he makes a joke. One of my favorite slice of life protagonists.

Also, shout out to Chris Patton. He was excellent as Yuuichi.


~ Ayu ~ UGUU That is all...

Nah, I'm kidding. I said I'd go into detail, didn't I? And there's more to her than just her 'catchphrase.' She is a very loud character, which may annoy some. But the appeal to her loudness is that she is just so cute and fun. Ayu is very playful, and has some of the best moments and conversations with Yuuichi in the series. This may sound odd, too, but she really is such a 'bro' in most of the arcs (I don't mean that she looks or acts like a boy, although Yuuichi does tease her about that. I trust that you're smart enough to know what I mean. I'm just not smart enough to find the right word for it haha). You can almost always count on her to cheer you, and Yuuichi, up in some of the darker moments of the series.

Not only that, but there is a mystery surrounding her... and her past with Yuuichi...


So those are the two main protagonists. Other characters, such as Kaori and Aunt Akiko, get a lot of screen time in most of the arcs, as well, and you do grow to like them a ton. And then of course, other female characters get the spotlight in different arcs, as well. These characters are:


~ Nayuki ~ "Do you still remember my name?"

- Yuuichi’s cousin and the captain of the track team, she is not a morning person and always seems kinda sleepy. She is incredibly adorable.


~ Makoto ~ "When spring comes...it would be nice if it would last forever." 

- A girl who lost her memories and likes to mess with Yuuichi. There is a lot more to her than that, but spoilers. That goes for practically all of these characters, by the way.


~ Mai ~ "...I'm a demon hunter." 

- A quiet and cold beauty who mysteriously comes to school at night with a sword and claims that she fights demons...


~ Shiori ~ "It's called a miracle because it doesn't happen." 

- A girl who is absent from school a lot because of some apparent cold. But, for some reason, she stands alone on the school courtyard everyday, saying that she is waiting to meet someone... 


The arcs tie together quite nicely, and don't seem out of place. The characters develop over the course of each arc, and although not all of the arcs have the happiest of endings, they sure are quite satisfying. I always want to see how Yuuichi will deal with these situations, and how they will change him.

And lastly, I'd like to mention Kitagawa: he's the funny 'best friend' character of this series, and he gets a decent amount of screentime. The reason why I like him is, and this is the only time I will compare Kanon to Clannad, don't worry; the reason why I liked him is that he felt a lot like Sunohara, which is pretty awesome because Sunohara is my favorite best friend character of all time. Kitagawa was funny and cared for his friends, and he has a LOT more character and personality in this anime than he did in the visual novel, so I give KyoAni props for that.


~ART/ANIMATION~ KyoAni did an amazing job with the art and animation. They actually made Yuuichi look like a human being (unlike that... other... thing that was made in 2002), and the girls are beautiful. The animation, for 2006, is really smooth and looks decent even by today's standards. It's excellent, and a pleasure to look at. It's not an eyegasm, like Nagi no Asukara, for example, but for the year it was made in, it's pretty great.


~SOUND~ I'll get this out of the way: the dub is actually really good. I already said this, but I'll say it again: Chris Patton was awesome as Yuuichi, and made him a more likable character. Brittney Karbowski was also a pretty good Ayu, but I wouldn't say that her performance as Ayu is better than Yui Horie's. The dub isn't as moe, or cute, as the Japanese version, but if you're okay with that, then the dub should be fine.

The sub is also amazing, so no problems there. Stick with sub if you want more adorable voices for the female characters.

The OST for this anime is very bouncy and peppy during the normal slice of life moments. The more touching scenes have more emotional music, so it all fits nicely, no song seems out of place. The OST is really good, and I listen to it on YouTube from time to time.

The OP is very slow and calming, and it's really quite beautiful. The first couple of notes really give off the feeling of winter. The ED is a very nice and happy song. I didn't ever skip either of them. To sum it up, the sound is also quite great.


So, all in all, Kanon is a beautiful anime, it really is. It's one of the best Key anime to date. But it can be a bit slow near the beginning for some, and especially during Mai and Makoto's arc, it can be a bit confusing and farfetched. And then I do have to mention that some people may not like Key's artstyle, so be wary of that (I personally love it though). But I assure you it all pays off in the end with it's cast of heartwarming characters, emotional and bittersweet story arcs, and great animation and OST.


Here are my ratings:


-Story ~ 8 ~

-Characters ~ 9 ~

-Art ~ 9 ~

-Animation ~ 8 ~

-Sound ~ 9 ~

-Enjoyment ~ 10 ~


Kanon has become one of my favorite anime. I am so happy that I rewatched it, and I will rewatch it many more times in the future. I hope anyone else who watches it finds this anime to be as wonderful as I did.

Kanon is a very special anime. I enjoyed it a lot despite the obvious major flaws it has. The flaws are so big that they would ruin almost any other anime. Kanon endured it. 
The story takes place in some small Japanese town in the middle of winter. 17-years old Yuuichi Aizawa comes to the town with an intention to study at local high school. His cute blue-haired cousin accommodates him. It's been 7 years since Yuuichi had last visited this town. Strangely, he doesn't remember anything from 7 years ago. During his stay in the town, he befriends several girls: hyperactive Makoto, lonely Shiori,quiet Mai and immature Ayu. As he is helping them with their struggles, he starts to remember his previous stay in the town. Little by little. 


The good:


The reason why Kanon is held in such high regard is by far the emotional impact. The anime floods the viewer with emotions in every single episode, especially in the last few ones. Another really good aspect of the anime is the art. In fact, it looks beautiful. As the anime is set in winter, most of the time we see the snow falling, but even such common scenery can look delightful. The afternoon scenes were even prettier; the sunlight was done neatly. Character art was solid, too. Perhaps their eyes could be a little smaller, but that's a nitpick. 


Every anime of course needs a good soundtrack. And Kanon has it. The music is tranquil all the time, you won't find any fist-pumping tunes here. It's for the best, though, as the music perfectly fits the story and art. Let's move to the bad now.


The bad:


I have a lot to say about the bad aspects of Kanon. First and foremost, Yuuichi sucks. His relationship with every girl I mentioned above seems like a relationship of two lovers. But then he helps the girl and moves on to another one. The one he helped before is completely forgotten as he is helping another one. Then in the end, he decides that he loves just one of them. They fall in love almost instantly without so much as a few episodes for their relationship to evolve.


That also shows that the pattern of the series is not done well. As with most anime, it's divided into arcs. In each arc, the main characters are Yuuichi and one of the girls. The pattern is like this: Yuuichi and the girl meet --> the next few episodes are about Yuuichi helping her --> they get extremely close --> Yuuichi remembers some of his memories --> problem is solved --> move on to another girl and forget about the previous one.


Another flaw is the unreality. I don't even mean the supernatural actions that occur here and there. What I mean is that for a slice of life anime, the characters don't act like real people at all. Yuuichi's total amnesia is quite stupid as well. He doesn't remember a lot of important things.


And finally, the most appealing trait of Kanon is also what it drags down. The emotionality is overblown. It's too melodramatic. The characters get teary-eyed because of sentiments. Certain emotional scenes are repeated too much. All in all, it could be done with less tears.


Conclusion:  


It probably looks like I hate this anime but no, I genuinely like it actually. It just has those flaws that are impossible to overlook plus I really wanted to comment on them. Kanon was not an easy anime to watch, but when i finished watching it, I couldn't help myself. The emotional impact was big and that's what it's supposed to be about.


PS: note how I wrote this review without mentioning Clannad.

"Do you know the title of this song? It's Canon. Pachelbel's Canon. It repeats the same melody and crescendos gradually, peacefully, and beautifully. It would be nice if life changed like that: slowly but surely, while being seemingly unchanged from day to day."
— Kurata Sayuri
Kanon 2006, if you don't already know, is the second attempt at adapting Key's 1999 visual novel  into the anime format.  I've not yet seen the original 2002 anime, but the visual novel was actually my first visual novel ever, and since reading it, I've watched the 2006 anime twice.  Needless to say, I wouldn't have watched 48episodes of anime if I didn't like the story.  So why the relatively low score?  Well, MAL's suggested rating scale calls 7/10 "good," so there's that, but why not a 10/10 masterpiece?  Read on, and I'll explain myself.


MAL suggests 5 categories for judging in reviews: story, art, sound, character, and enjoyment.  So first off, I'll discuss the story.  You already have a synopsis written for you on the anime's page, so I'll just boil it down to "17 year old boy moves back to the town he left when he was 10, doesn't really remember anything, acquires harem of girls, drama ensues."  Now, the anime improved pretty greatly on the visual novel in some areas, which I'll get to later, but the story suffered a bit from the adaptation.  In the visual novel, there are five different story routes, one per heroine, and the choices you make decide which route you follow.  Each route takes place primarily in the month of January, and has its own dramatic and romantic happenings that don't usually bleed into other routes.  It works very well, and the stories of the individual routes (or character arcs, in the anime adaptation) are generally quite good.  Two routes in particular -- I won't say which -- stood out above the rest, in my eyes, in the visual novel, though one of those two (the one that affected me most in the visual novel, unfortunately) suffered a bit in the anime.  The other is still phenomenal, and I still teared up at one point despite having already experienced it twice before -- the first time, I have to admit, I bawled my eyes out >.> And that wasn't the only time, either. If there's one thing Jun Maeda is good at, it's creating very emotionally moving drama.


The biggest problem with the anime adaptation, though, comes from trying to connect those five independent routes from the visual novel in a coherent way.  KyoAni did the best they could (the best anyone could, really), but it still wasn't quite good enough.  For one thing, it's kind of...drama-overload at times, if you know what I mean.  In the visual novel, they're separate stories, but in the anime, you basically end up getting five stories' worth of drama packed into one.  And it doesn't help that so much of it is so similar -- half the characters suffer from plot-device amnesia, and/or "Key AIDS."  On their own, each dramatic happening is very well done, but all in a row, it feels a bit excessive.  Some of it just isn't even necessary -- there's one particular moment in one of the later episodes where a bit of drama just slams right into you out of nowhere, and I actually laughed out loud at how sudden and unnecessary it was.  The romance aspect suffers from adaptation decay, perhaps even more than the dramatic aspect.  There's a point in the series where Pimp Daddy Yuuichi gets the cutest kiss ever from one girl, and you're all "awwwwwww :'3," but then literally one episode later, he's kissed by and confesses his love to a different girl who had barely even appeared at all in the previous several episodes.  I was re-watching it with my girlfriend, who'd never seen nor read it before, and I believe her exact words were "whoa, what? Sudden!"  I had to shrug my shoulders and say, "just pretend he hasn't been involved with any of the other girls and roll with it."  The last problem with the story that arose from adapting all the arcs into one linear story was the final episode.  I won't spoil anything, but it's rather forced and confusing.  People say that about Clannad After Story's ending, but this is significantly harder to swallow, in my opinion.  It doesn't ruin the whole story, but it does cost it yet more points.


Now, onto art!  As I mentioned earlier, the original visual novel came out in 1999, and the art for it was...less than stellar.  Frankly, I don't think it was any worse than the art I've seen from the 2002 anime, but it's still pretty ugly.  The 2006 KyoAni art, though, is MUCH better.  Yeah, okay, their mouths and noses are still almost comically tiny and in the very center of their faces (except for the males), but it definitely looks good if you aren't bothered by that aspect of the style.  The animation isn't always completely fluid, but it's definitely much better than average.  Even if it's 2006 KyoAni, it IS still KyoAni we're talking about here.


Sound is definitely a strong point of Kanon's, and of everything Maeda does the sound for.  His compositions set the mood perfectly, 100% of the time.  Well, other than the ED song, maybe, which is sometimes jarringly bright and cheery after a dramatic cliffhanger episode ending, but I won't hold that against it.  The OP is fantastic, and every background track is perfect.  The voice acting is solid, as well, in the original Japanese.  Not a fan of the English dub, due to uguu, auu, etc.  10/10 sound.


Character...This is a bit of a tricky category.  On the one hand, the bulk of the cast are little more than one-dimensional moeblobs, but on the other hand...they are SO MOE.  I'm not usually a "moe" guy, but geez.  Maeda knows how to write some moe waifus.  Frankly, the romantic aspects of certain routes -- particularly the h-scenes in the original visual novel -- felt a bit awkward to me, because not only do many of the girls look incredibly young, but they also *ACT* incredibly young, often giving off less of a "girlfriend" vibe and more of a "pet puppy dog" vibe, if you know what I mean.  It's not a huge deal, since ultimately all that matters for the viewer, in this case, is that he or she becomes attached to the characters and wants (Yuuichi) to love and protect them, and I think most viewers would agree that Key was successful there.  Some people might find the characters to be "obnoxious moeblobs," but most will adore them.  My girlfriend thought Ayu was annoying at first, but it didn't take too long for her to fall in love with her :P


Enjoyment is the trickiest category, I think.  I mean, typically, if I gave the other categories high scores, I'd give this one a high score, and if I gave the others low scores, I'd give this a low score, you know?  But I can't just average them together and call that my enjoyment score, because for me, it was more than just the sum of its parts.  I criticized the various failings of the story earlier, but when I first read the visual novel years ago, I adored it.  I knew the art was bad, and I knew the plot depended on too many conveniently forgotten memories and "Key Magic," but I didn't care.  It made me laugh, it made me cry, it made me gasp, it made me sigh...It just moved me, emotionally, more strongly than most anything in fiction.  I really enjoyed it.  I didn't enjoy the anime quite as much, but the visual novel might have made me slightly biased compared to a viewer who's never read it.  That doesn't erase the flaws in the story that I described earlier, but they might not bother new viewers as much as they bothered me.


So to sum it up, Kanon is a VERY emotional, though somewhat flawed story, with solid art for its time, lovable characters, and the perfect musical score.  It's not perfect, and viewers less tolerant of forced drama, moeblobs, and "Key Magic" will probably tear it apart, but I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who thinks they might be interested.  Watch it in the snowy winter, with someone or something to hug when things get serious.  I think you'll enjoy it.

Welcome to Kanon, a place where miracles happen, a wintry town where time has stopped, a town where the lost memories of a child will unfold magical stories. A town that needs to move again.
The amount of symbolism this anime uses might be the reason why I feel this anime is magical, yet, the meaning behind it is realistic, heartwarming and bittersweet.
The story follows up Yuuichi as he is returning to the wintry town where he used to spent his childhood. He is waiting for Nayuki, his cousin: a purple (or violet?) haired girl. While Yuuichi has his memories screwed he still manages to rememberNayuki's name... kinda, but you can never tell as Yuuichi has the special ability to tease girls like a pro. Moving ahead, we reach Nayuki's home. Where her adorable mother Akiko is waiting for them. And thus Yuuichi will start his life in this cold but warm town as a transfer student.


As Yuuichi starts familiarizing with the highschool and its surroundings we will come to a loop. A loop where the characters from the upcoming arcs will be introduced. At first I thought that Yuuichi was trying to form a harem for himself, acting like a casanova while he teases girls non-stop, yet, I was merely fooling myself as the first arc strikes and makes me realize that this is much more than just a guy trying to be nice to everyone. In reality, the lost memories of this wintry town are clashing into Yuuichi's mind as he is trying to remember what happened in his childhood. 


Unless you live under a rock, you'll probably know that Key's works tend to go around several girls, and also, the need to be utterly tragic. Gladly, this isn't the case with Kanon as it focuses more on relationships and memories. Yet that doesn't mean that this will not be an emotional ride and have some tragic moments on it. Each arc on its own is full on substance and meaningful moments that will be important when the story approaches its end. And then, the flow of time will resume its course.


KyoAni is known for having beautiful visuals on their anime, yet, I'm honestly surprised by the animation quality an anime from 2006 has. The backgrounds are gorgeous and full of meaning, which is lacking on KyoAni's recent works, they might have improved their animation quality, but the substance and meaning behind it's dull and may flood the screen causing an overdose of animation while the meaning gets lost behind, Violet Evergarden is a perfect example of that.


While most of the time I always wonder why these anime uses such a very childish design for females, I can say that I really liked their designs as the show introduces these girls while making you get easily attached to them and feeling the need to hug them and pat their heads.


Each arc improves the meaning behind the animation, making each moment heartwarming, and sometimes bittersweet depending on the mood, and for that, I loved it.


While the animation was doing a great job on their department, the sound department made a good job portraying it's meaning into a great selection of soundtracks, depending on the mood they will either be funny, calm, sad, heartwarming or bittersweet. The voice acting was good, even for me who totally dislikes the use of very childish voices for girls, yet, the emotions put on the characters did really stand out and worked well.


As I said before, each character arc is really important and almost every single character is meaningful to the story... with the exception of Kitagawa Jun, who is mostly there as comic relief. (in the end, he ends being a cheerful Savior) Each girl arc has a different focus but the meaning behind each one of them will help squeezing Yuuichi's brain while having glances of his childhood, gradually recovering part of his memories. Some of these arcs might be quite fantastical and surreal, but once you know what it means you'll understand. 


Kanon's characters are easy to get attached to, and you'll probably end up liking these characters unless you have a thing against Key's works or just don't like them. Either way, the characters are one of the strongest points of this anime.


Enjoyment 8/10: I enjoyed Kanon from start to end, its heartwarming and bittersweet moments holds a special place in my heart as it resembles a similar story of one of my relatives. 


Overall: 7,6 (8)/10

Oh my,, just finished this anime, and my pillow has never been so wet with tears =).
In the beginning I had a hard time with the characters. They sort of felt strange and not believeable at all. As the episodes went by they sort of grew up and you start to understand what is happening and suddenly everything from the start to the end is like a beautiful dream that comes true. If you have a lot of tears to spare and can cope with the first episodes you will have a great time with this anime series!

I will try to be brief and point out, in my opinion, the main advantages and disadvantages
So "Kanon" made by studio "Key" in 2000, visual novel gets a new show in 2006, well let's look at it.
A boy named Yuichi arrives in the city of his childhood, after 7 years. Also he does not remember anything and gradually, in this city, he meets girls "from the past", which involves a lot of tragic stories and helps them.
To be honest, the show is very dramatic, but it banality. Like all the rules of the studio "Key" and what they have always been strong, we havea school and a number of different women with different stories that are revealed in the process, and we learn about their dramatic fate. The problem with all of these ideas is that after the story of a girl, the story abruptly switches to another character, and that in the last series was still a major, it moves into the background, If not disappear from the frame at all.


It begins pretty standard, we show several women, but did not disclose their stories as if they are present, as ordinary characters. At first glance, it may seem that this is a standart "slice of life", but the story progresses at an early stage, the dream, as it were, takes us to look beyond story. And yet, in all this story is based on supernatural powers - that is, miracles, and I will not say it's bad, because that was a miracle, we must believe in it.

As for the characters, they are good, for each character, made a separate character stories associated with them.


Of course, like all works of the studio "Key", after about 8 episodes, the viewer becomes interested in the fate of the protagonist and supporting characters, and here is no exception. Kanon attracts attention better and better with each episode and certainly causes a lot of emotions.


And most importantly, in my opinion, in this show, it's a music. Each series has a musical name, such as "Songs without Words" or "The Nocturne of Farewell ." A lot of beautiful piano in the background, which plays almost constantly. Maeda Jun - music genius, skillfully plays on the feelings at some point in the series (Not surprisingly, because he has always been good in the genres: music, drama and school).


The conclusion to this series is a subtle point, since in spite of a good idea and excellent execution of it, the anime does not avoid the banal situations that are based on standards, which, in turn, are not an experienced viewer can not see. However, Kanon fine plays on the feelings that course and is required by the genre drama, fans of this genre (Drama and Harem),will love it, because it is made at a good level


Kanon - it's a drama, performed at the highest level, but only within the limits of the genre, but in any case it is worthy of attention and interest the viewer.
