I would suggest to almost anyone besides those Shonen Straight out action guys whos favorites are Naruto, One Piece, and Dragon Ball Z. 


Have fun watching!

In a city called Amnesia. Wait, sorry, that’s not it. In a city where the main character has terrible amnesia, everyone is prone to sickness and accident, and echoes of better things to come echo resoundingly (namely, Clannad), there’s a guy named Yuuichi. He’s moved in with his aunt, as he did seven years previously. His memories of that winter break are really hazy, borderline Elfen Lied syndrome. But he met a lot of people and affected a lot of lives in that break, and his return is the culmination of what he started seven years before. This is set off by the perky andcute Ayu, a girl he knows, but doesn’t know. This continues with a chance meeting with a mischievous girl named Makoto and continues from there.


Kanon has the same set up as Clannad in that Yuuichi meets a host of girls who have some problems that he attempts to quell. The romantic interest is hard to guess because he seems so close to so many girls, but in the end there is one constant girl who he winds up with. A lot of the same elements as Clannad come up as well, especially prevalent being the supernatural aspect and the coma. Of course, this is the precursor to Clannad and should be treated as such now that we can look back at it. While it has a lot of failings, it is the start.


Kanon’s story isn’t great, but it’s not bad. The problem with the story is how forced the depressing parts seem. I don’t  know how many times the series tries to make me feel bad for characters by having their parents or themselves come down with unnamed diseases. The first time it was boring and cheap, the fourth time it was stupid. The series doesn’t leave many characters without scarring and while I can commend it for having balls, I can’t commend it for continually forcing me to watch scene after scene of shocked and sad characters after finding out their friends or family have been hurt or come down with disease. There are certain points where you will have a shocked expression sitting on your face because a  bad thing has come out of left field. though, and these are the most effective.


Makoto, Mai, and Shiori’s sections of the story are all decently done, but none of it really stands out. The gradual progression of the disappearance of Makoto is nicely done and may be the only subtle part of the series. You know what’s going to happen, and you feel for Makoto. Mai is different in the fact that none of what she does is really dramatic, I felt like I was watching a supernatural high school action anime instead of a drama. The part about her mother was groan-worthy, especially because it was the second sickness in the series. The drama came more so at the end of this storyline, and was fairly stupid in my opinion. Shiori’s section, for me, was pretty archetypical and boring. It made nice progress character development-wise, but was otherwise nothing exciting and brought up the fourth instance of sickness (the third being Aunt Akiko). And then more happens to Aunt Akiko and this was one of the few moments I was left with my jaw dropped. As I said, it came out of nowhere and it hurt pretty bad.


Where the story is good is with the final section, dedicated to Ayu. As I watched it, I felt like I was watching Tomoya and Fuko from Clannad getting together. I was seeing characters I already know. And I was so happy too. I knew what was coming, but it was still emotionally riveting and dramatic to watch this storyline unfold, and an especially happy moment at the end. I felt that the romance between Ayu and Yuuichi was a little rushed, and he didn’t seem as into her as he did Shiori or the other girls, but nonetheless it was still heartfelt.


The series as a whole can be considered forced drama, but there are moments that are seriously heartfelt and well done. And a lot of the good drama comes from the excellent cast of characters.


The characters are really moe, but that’s okay. The personalities are all different, and while some are archetypical, some are a little different. Each character develops and grows on you, even Yuuichi, which I find commendable. Usually the main male character is someone you could give a crap less about, a piece of cardboard being thrown around and rejecting any advances while simultaneously being an asshole to everyone he meets. Yuuichi is the opposite. While he is a snarky and sarcastic guy, he is, at heart, good. He does everything he can to help these girls and the fact that he cries over one of them just goes to show how different he is from the rest. He knows the right way to deal with everything, and while his seeming amnesia is a nuisance (though part of that is explained later on) he’s overall the best character in the entire show.


Oh, and Jun is Sunohara.


Why bring all this stuff about Clannad up? Because if you liked Clannad, you’ll love Kanon. If you loved Kanon, you’ll love Clannad. There are a lot of similarities, especially in the style of how the show progresses, but both provide great drama and great characters.


In Kanon there’s only that one problem of forced drama, though; the fact that bad things are prone to happen to everyone. And while the happy ending is nice, you spend the entire show feeling like you’re being made to cry or feel bad. As stated, there are points where things work and painful scenes are painful, there are points where it’s boring as hell.


Despite all the issues, it’s still a thoroughly enjoyable anime. I laughed, I cried, I met new friends and found myself meeting old ones in different bodies. Never is it bad, it just never hits the stride that Clannad eventually will.


If you’re looking for drama and characters you’ll grow to love, then give Kanon a shot.

So, this review will be pretty short; due to that this is my first review.
The story revolves around some dude named Yuuichi. Y'know he's just your average generic guy. But anyways; he forms a romance with 5 girls through the anime. The romance however was pretty decent. They could had done more work on the character development on the romantic side of things. But love isn't the only thing about this anime. The main story is; when Yuuichi travels back to I think his home town, he re-unites with his childhood friends. But for some reason, Yuuichi doesn't remember any of them, nor the layoutof the town it self. And minor spoiler alert, all 5 of those girls are his childhood friends. 


And now that we have discussed a small run-down of the story, we are now moving on to my least favorite part of this anime. And that's the drama. Now since I liked Clannad, I was kinda expecting it to be kinda like that, and it is, but THEY MILKED IT WAY TOO MUCH! I'm not gonna tell you what happens, but you'll understand for yourself. I found  this anime to be very cliché, and easily predictable. And because of that, I am giving this anime an 8 out of 10, because that really did kill the experience for me.


Final Thoughts:


Now this isn't a bad anime. I actually found it to be very good, but that drama was milked a little too much. But this anime is defintly worth a watch; if you're a fan of the romantic drama genre. Me? I'm more of a fan of romantic comedy's, so you might enjoy this anime more if you love drama. 


Final Score: 8 out of 10 [Very Good].

I think the plot is similar to that of CLANNAD but has its own style. Aizawa Yuuichi, a high school student who is welcomed by many girls, just like Okazaki Tomoya in CLANNAD. But Aizawa Yuuichi has a bad memory so he forgot a lot of things that were happened seven years ago and tried to remind of them gradually. Since the anime is remade from the visual novel with the same name, Aizawa Yuuichi-san will have different storied with different girls. And I think these characters are similar:
  * Tsukimiya Ayu ≈ Ibuki Fuko
  * Minase Akio ≈ Sanae Furukawa
  *Kitagawa Jun ≈ Sunohara Youhei\n\n
My favourate character is Tsukimiya Ayu, because she is a kawaii loli desu, just like Ibuki Fuko in CLANNAD. She regards taiyaki as her favourate food and Ibuki Fuko in CLANNAD regards starfish as her favourate things.\n\n
My second favourate character is Sawatari Makoto, who is kawaii too and says kawaii "Auu~" from time to time. The story about Sawatari Makoto made me tear up.\n\n
Key is really an amazing company which creates these awesome stories.

With better art quality and a more in depth story than the 2002 version, this is the one you want to watch, if any.
The trendsetter for Key’s Crying Game anime series...es, Kanon presates a strong legacy, and features a lot of the tropes which become commonplace among their series. The asshole with the heart of gold, the potential harem situation, the ‘one best friend’ guy, the inexplicable deaths and suffering, and more suffering. All that good stuff.
Kanon is chock full of weird and wonderful characters, and as long as you don’t mind the gender imbalance (about 10:2), then there’s something for everyone.
Yuuichi Aizawa moves backto a town he used to stay in for the winter, and immediately becomes reacquainted with some old friends he’d completely forgotten about. Huh. Weird.\n\n
His aunt and cousin keep prodding his memory, to see if any synapses fire, but it seems poor Yuuichi is a complete amnesiac about the whole situation. The show does a very good job at keeping you suspicious about this, until it sideswipes you completely by having several characters sustain horrific accidents, with little to no warning sometimes. However, all the time you’ve invested in getting to know the characters isn’t a waste, because once Yuuichi gets his memory back, and finds out why he left in the first place, the granddaddy of Deus Ex Machinas happens, and everyone miraculously recovers!\n\n
...so yeah, a less than ideal finish. But don’t let that put you off watching it. It has some brilliant humour, a solid storyline (sans the above), and a really likeable bunch of characters. It’s not their best, but it was certainly a good starting point. After all, with future references and cameos, you could say it was Kanon by name, Canon by nature.

To me, this show will always be a classic. While older compared to anime today, it was and still is a all time favorite of mine. The intro, BGM and just the characters in general are all great. While the beginning is a little slow to start in my opinion, it has a few funny scenes to help out during that time. Then, when the good part starts. Things get serious and it becomes a series that literally had me in tears. This show literally made me looking for anime like this or even better than this, when it first aired. I was now exploringand holding other shows to this standard or higher because it was one of the first anime I had watched that gave me so much emotion in it. So, should you watch this? Yes, you will not regret it when you complete this series.

Kanon, like the Pachelbel composition that supplied its name, flows gently and warmly, a tender tugging of heartstrings possessing fathomless depth of heart.  It is quiescent and bittersweet, nearly as despairing as comforting, its direction instantly recognizable to most but no less capable of sweeping the audience along in its wake.
Beset by tragedy, framed by the cruel iniquities of life and the merciful concessions of a magical world, Kanon trudges on, resolute and passionate.  These Key visual novel-based series have reputations for being “feel factories” – shamelessly melodramatic, exploitative of characters’ plight for the sake of provoking reactions from the audience – andsuch a judgment would not be unjustified, but perhaps premature in regard to Kanon.  The characters do suffer, both outwardly and inwardly, due to random misfortune, each other, and themselves; no tale can be told without some of the players enduring hardship for the telling.  Kanon is not cruel.  It employs coincidence and callbacks, but rarely contrivance; perhaps some of the situations are unrelatable, at least in literal aspect, but the show never reaches such a fantastical mood that it becomes the dire, farcical tear-jerker it is sometimes painted as.  


The obvious appeal of Kanon is the timeworn conceit of one amiable, inoffensive male lead whiling away the episodes with a variety pack of cute girls, but the show is packed with aesthetic detail that opens a much different angle of attraction, and one unique to Kanon.  Nestled in a snow-capped country town where time seems to bear little urgency and every day brings with it endless opportunities, Kanon begins as a relaxing, easygoing show, a gorgeously consumable work of classic moe.  The dreamlike environs slowly fade into color with a distant voice-over from Ayu, who opens many episodes with a sad, nostalgic observation to herself.  Pillowed drifts blanket the scenery, illuminated by the soft light of streetlights and sunset; the color palette, while not dull, is hardly striking, favoring basic, strong, wholesome hues.  The girls speak in soft, airy voices, each one of them equipped with their own adorable catchphrase.  Their character designs, though perhaps somewhat out of fashion now with their feathery hair and gigantic eyes, are stylish and appealing, both incredibly sharp in comparison to the 2002 anime and mellow enough to live up to the moe aesthetic.  The mood is calm, the temperament warm and reassuring, like a hearty fire in the midst of a roaring winter.  Most of the time, nobody even makes any sudden movements.  Enriched by strings and chimes from the heart-wrenching OP to the catchy ED, Kanon’s soundtrack perfectly embodies and enhances the show like few other soundtracks (smart move borrowing so heavily from the source material there).  More than anything else, Kanon is calm and soothing, a wintry wonderland straight out of a fairy tale that cannot be extricated from its pure, snowy trappings.


It would not take long for any viewer to ascertain whether or not they have the wherewithal to sit through 24 episodes of a Kanon-like show, and Kanon is nothing if not a genre show in that it fully relies on the audience buying into the premise and aesthetic in order to go anywhere.  In that sense, Kanon may be nothing greater than an excellent example of its genre, proof that nothing in this world can defeat Kyoto Animation when it sets out to make a cute show.  As such a work, however, Kanon is exquisite.  The girls’ arcs (routes, in a former life) are sometimes cliché, sometimes unexpected, but always delivered with enough attention to audio/visual landscapes and natural performances to inspire every last iota of narrative.  As the show progresses, of course, the drama heightens and circumstances take marked turns for the worse (a famously emotional work like this can’t remain sunny and innocuous forever, after all), but somehow, in the midst of the suffering that plagues the characters, Kanon never loses its grip on its enveloping atmosphere.  The show isn’t wanton in its destruction, nor does it hold the viewer’s hand so much that the misfortunes lose their impact and urgency; Kanon walks the line between. 


When criticism must be voiced, it may be levied at the usual suspects: the protagonist, Yuuichi, who is sensitive, good-humored, and attractive in that barely-descript way that only the male leads in these romantic schemes can muster; the format, which has been revisited so often that its hackneyed conceit barely warrants comment; the ability of the show to move from one relationship to another without seeming to lose steam or dwell on the past; etc.  For myself, these complaints held little weight, as I, in accordance with my previous descriptions, set as much stock in the show’s atmosphere as in its narrative, but nonetheless found the narrative highly compelling and became invested in each arc even though the “true route” is obvious.  The characters are easy to love and easy to cheer for.


Kanon is flushed with spirit and earnestness, and whether or not the concept is tiresome has no bearing on this show’s execution of it; Kanon is competent and well-designed, but more than that, heartwarming and lovely.

This is one of my favorite anime series of all time. I will always hold this series dear, for it is beautiful. Forgive me if I sound overly emotional and cheesy, but I really love Kanon 2006. Everything about it is amazing.
Story: 9
The story in Kanon starts off simple at first, then becomes much more complex as the story progresses. It starts off with Yuichi Aizawa, who returns to his hometown where he spent his childhood. He moves in with his cousin Nayuki Minase, and as he befriends some of the people in the town, he starts to remember some of his suppressed memories ofhis childhood, which cause lots of drama and tear-jerking scenes to follow. Really, the stories were all developed amazingly, save for Nayuki's. I won't spoil any of it, but I do feel that Nayuki's arc wasn't focused on as much as the others, which is a shame since it is one of my favorites. However, besides that, every other story was unique and touching, and I even cried at points.


Art: 10

The art is great, and the animation is one of the best I have seen, even more so than the animation in some of the anime series of now. Some find the facial proportions of most of the female characters to be strange, considering how big the eyes are and the mouth placement and all that, but honestly, I didn't really see much wrong with that. I thought the art was cute. Plus, the backgrounds are super detailed and very realistic.


Sound: 10

The voice acting is phenomenal, and the music (all of the music) is superb, as expected from Key and Kyoto Animation. Each voice actor/actress puts their all in each character, and they are all very emotional and passionate. The music sets the atmosphere for the scenes flawlessly. The opening and ending songs are wonderful, also.


Character: 9

Each character is developed fully, and even the male protagonist's character is developed a lot. Unlike lots of male leads in harem series, Yuichi has personality and charm. Although some of the girls admittedly fell under some of the harem personality stereotypes, this wasn't too much of a problem.


Enjoyment: 10

This anime, in my opinion, was very enjoyable. The funny moments made me laugh, and the sad moments made me emotional, and even made me shed tears. I felt attached to all of the characters. Every factor mentioned in this review contributes greatly to the enjoyment of this anime.


Overall: 10

I have a tender spot for this anime, for it is one of the few that has really made me feel a vast series of emotions. The ending made me feel happy, and I love every character and, well, everything about this series. Every time I watch it, I still feel the same emotions as I did when I first viewed it. There is a vast amount of good anime, but few anime series are this astounding.

Memories are a mysterious thing… when you remember something, you are positive that what you remember is true, but memories can play tricks on you. Sometime the mind chooses what it wants to remember, and disregards what might be a painful or sad event. Memories are like a canon. A canon is a simple melody played repeatedly and after each line, a new melody is played on top of the existing melody, until it grows more complex. This (admittedly complicated) analogy ties very neatly into Kanon.
Another fantastic Key anime, Kanon is all about vague memories, and discovering how different memories tie together. I will notgo into plot points, save that it begins with the main character, Yuuichi, transferring to a small town to live with his Aunt Akiko, and cousin Nayuki. He meets a number of eccentric characters as the days go by, such as Ayu, a rambunctious squirt who is never without a cry of “uguu,” Shiori, a quiet, beautiful mystery of a girl, Asuka Lan- oh sorry, I mean Makoto, the loud one with a soft side, aka tsundere, and Mai and Sayuri, two seniors with a strong connection. Suffice it to say, Yuuichi gets close to each one of these girls, and makes for a very deep story. 


This will not be a long review, but to start, I have never been this attached to any shows characters as much as in Kanon. I cried during this show more times than I care to admit, particularly during one tear-jerking scene in ep 9. In addition, during the last 3 eps, I think I had tears in my eyes the entire time, but thankfully they changed to tears of joy at the end. It’s rare to see an anime this well put together, and able to make you care about its characters this deeply. I particularly love the use of Pachabel’s Canon in D, throughout the show, as well as “Once Upon a Dream” from Sleeping Beauty during a certain scene. As far as I know, that’s what that song is from… if anyone cares to correct me on that fact, go right ahead. If I had to complain about anything, it would be Yuuichi’s school chum, Jun. In my opinion, he only exists to break the mood of the show, except for one hilarious scene with Yuuichi. Other than Jun, I have no real complaints about this show. I only have praise for its characters and its story development, and its powerful emotion that it carries. It comes strongly recommended from me.

A quick review of my favourite anime of all time (so far). My first written review!!! AHHHH!!!
Story:
The story is not your typical harem as people might make it about to be whenever they see the word 'harem'. It plays out like a slice-of-life comedy in the beginning which may seem like a harem to most people, but the jokes are not as O.T.T as other harems in the past. Though with that, people might be incredibly bored throughout because all they are seeing is a slice-of-life comedy, nothing is progessively changing with the exception of the character interactions, which are very entertaining. Then it takesa cleverly thought out tonal and atmosphere change around the near halfway point and transforms into a deep and emotional journey and experience. This helps it's once bored audience to be one the edge of their seats and to be invested in what is happening to our beloved characters. But the story is just a catalyst to the real heart of the anime, but I'll get to that later. It's also worth noting that the story is very well written. Easily one of the best anime screenplays I've seen. As the dialogue is witty and natural. There is also a lot of subtext and undertones.


Art:

Kanon is one of Kyoto Animations finest works. It is simply wonderful. The character designs are moe granted, but the character animation is very fluent and the designs are at least consistent. The backgrounds are one of the best I've ever seen on how it's so detailed on how they draw snow. The lighting successfully compliments the atmosphere of the show, exposing us to daytime to afternoon to moonlight. In short, the art is phenomenal.


Sound:

I watched this series in dub rather than in sub because watching animes in English is just how I prefer it. Anyway, the dub is  one of the more bearable dubs I've watched despite having our characters looking so adorable. Many people have been complaining that the dub doesn't even try to attempt at being cute and incorperating moe, but I don't think that they were intending to have moe into the dub and that for me works better because you don't want to have cute girls to hinder your enjoyment of the show or overshadow the characters personalities and traits. The performances in the dub are well acomplished beacuse they actually have the emotions right off the bat. And they overall fit the characters, yes that goes for Ayu as well!


The soundtrack is not only my favourite anime soundtracks, but one of my favourite soundtracks, period. I just adore it. While the kind of tracks they have might not be the most original thing out there, they are well worth remembering after a YEAR first watching it. The tracks consist of a full orchestra. It mainly consist of canons which are pieces of music are on loop, but have a definitive ending and leaves you with a different feeling each time. The happier music has the piano,drum beats, wind and if you listen closely you can hear a synthesizer. But for the emotional scenes you have full on strings and a piano, they are just a beautiful sound and are they ones I remember the most, but I do appreciate the happier tunes too. It is a very clever score and unmistakeably beautiful.


Characters:

But the real heart of the show lies in the characters. The cast is literally what made the show for me. They have so many varying personalty traits that it feels like that you're not seeing the same character twice. Another thing that is so great about them is that they have so much mystery to their character, going back to the story serving as a catalyst and having all this mystery pile up on each other makes up for some of the best moments of the series as you're constantly figuring out to find out the secrets of the girls. Speaking of which, while the girls maybe cute, they are constantly being put in situations that real life people unfortunately face, which on paper may sound very much melodramatic as it can possibly can be, but these characters are so distinctivly human that it pays off. It also shows that Yuichi shares genuine chemistry with the girls, well that is mainly due to the fact that he met most of the girls seven years prior.


Enjoyment:

This series was enjoyable from beginning to end always successfully getting a reaction out of me. This may seem like a cute show at first but it evolves into something unimaginable, like a dream, which is coincidentally one of things the series talks about! While a happy and inspirational show, it was also a tragically sad and realistic story with supernatural elements involved. And some of the moments are so depressing, it's easily one of the saddest piece of media I've ever seen and one of the few to actually make me cry to something that isn't animal related. I would love to talk about these moments, what effect they had on me and the ending, but it would just ruin it for you. Kanon is something that should be seen to believe, because not only is it my favourite anime of all time, it's the anime that actually change my life, make new friends, made me a better person and was the anime to make me an otaku and to believe that without anime I would've been lost in this world, but I still but family, friends and school first!


Overall:

Kanon (2006) is not only a brilliant anime, but brilliant television. It's just wonderful. The story and its characters are well written and deeply developed, the animation is brillant and the music is beautiful. It is definitely a 'diamond-in-the-rough' in the harem genre, but also an experience. I would definitely recommend it to anyone because I believe it is the most realistic drama I've ever seen. It's my favourite of the three Key visual novels to anime adaptations and would be my favourite anime for quite a long time. Just go watch it now while you still can!


To see more reviews from me, check out IrishAnimefan on YouTube. Slán.

Let us begin with what this anime is about. Aizawa returns to this little city to live with his aunt and cousin, but for some unknown reason, he doesn't remember much of his past that he spent in the city. Of course his memory impairment provide support for the plot and pushes it along in the episodes. From the creators of "Clannad" this story provides the same emotional trauma, shaking you to tears, with crazy plot twists that seem unreasonable and supernatural, but remains in good taste.
Now you may be saying that "oh this guy is some softy push over wimp," but you sir arewrong! THIS IS AN ANIME WHICH CLEARLY INTENDS TO BRING A TEAR JERKING PLOT AND SUCCEEDS! If you ever saw me in person, you wouldn't think of me as such the type to cry, but this anime is one of the few that could make me!


*Cough


Excuse my rant, but anyways, if you like Clannad or anything like Bokura Ga Ita, and even Lamune (if you've seen it), you'll love this anime.


10/10 (>'.')>I Heart this Anime

Kanon 2006 has a lot of emotions in it. How shall I describe it? An anime of many miracles... cute, funny, sad, its a relationship builder. Yes, I think that's a great way for describing it, a relationship builder. A boy who makes many friends while staying with his aunt, as a child. And then completely forgetting them, only to become friends with them all over again seven years later. Theres a very little bit of action, not much. And not every moment made sense until the end of the anime.
I think it surprised me how real the characters made the anime feel. I reallydid get lost inside that world somehow. To regain his memory, Yuuichi had to go through a lot of trials, he had to lose and regain them to realize their importance. To me this anime had a sweet and yet tragic taste. A never ending dream, and yet at the same time, reality. I think this anime deserves its rating of nine because it really did keep me glued to my seat this time around. 


But I really should be honest; it took me three tries to get through this anime. Okay, so I started watching Kanon (2006) a few years back. I couldn't decide if I wanted to watch it in English or Japanese at the time. So I tried watching the first episode in japanese but out of curiosity I started it over and swiched to english. Normally I'd be fine just watching an anime in japanese with subs, but after hearing the voices in english it sort of just stuck. I decided to watch it in english because after making it through the first episode I realized that most of the voice actors I had grown up listening to.


At that time I only got to about episode 7 or 8 before I moved on to watch something else. I decided I'd watch it some other time. Finally this year I started watching it from the beginning again. And before I knew it I was far beyond where I stopped the first time. I was able to finish all 24 episodes in about 4 days, that's how much I enjoyed it.

other than personally being a little irritated by the speed that the story concludes with, this anime is super, the plot is great, really draws you in and has some suprise twists to it aswel. the art is outstanding, really easy to watch and makes the characthers really come to life. the sound is also flawless, none of the voices were even remotley annoying for me, which is rare, even shows ive given a 10 too sometimes have 1 characther who's voice annoys me, other than that the sound is agian flawless. the characthers are exceptional, i felt i really understood them, theyre all thesort of people, i think i would want to be friends with if they were real. overall enjoyment was a 9, had the last few episodes been a little less rushed (atleast imo they were a touch) then it would have hit 10, really easy and fun to watch, made me smile all the way through, though there are a couple of really sad, emotionally gripping moments too. so a 9 overall is imo the fairest score i can give, its not quite a 10, but its as close as it can come without being one.

Ok now this is a very difficult anime to review, mainly because, well, it’s not really an anime everyone talks about even if you've seen it. But here goes.
Story - The story is fairly simple going and has a new "main" (I use the word main loosely here) plot every 5 or so episodes because they slowly introduce new characters and their problems until the big finally which I can guarantee not a single one of you will see coming, but its great no matter how you look at it. For the vast majority of the episodes it serious with a load of comedy thrownin and even if you see it coming it’s still one of the funniest things you'll see. But it does have its serious side, like the death of a character and romance between friends and the first plot you're given is the main character trying to regain his memories of this town from when he was young.


Art - well the art in this I basic the only bit that really stands out is the "demons" that we see latter in the series and to be totally honest their not all that special either but don’t get me wrong the animation is good but it just doesn’t stand out.


Sound - now this is basically the same as the art, nothing really stands out, and the only real praise I can give the sound is there are some really good voice actors used and an interesting catchphrase for one of the characters.


Characters - well in Kanon (2006) there’s a character for everyone there’s your moe there’s your clown, the hopeless one, the sporty one I think there literally is a character for everyone and everyone will love little Ayu-Ayu.


Enjoyment/Overall - this is an anime that is you don’t see it you're missing out big time, heck, every time I’ve been to a convention (most recently Wai-con 09) somehow I always end up talking to at least one person (who I meet there) about Kanon (2006) and how good it is and how everyone should see it, so be there or be square!

This anime easily went to my #1 favorite. It took my man card away. Not joking... There's a big hole in my wallet now. 10/10

Kanon may not be the best anime I've watched, but it's still an anime worth watching. 
  Production wise, I think they did a fine job here. The animation is pretty gorgeous to look at. The crisp backgrounds and design of the characters make the tone really stand out. Combine that with the stellar sound, and it stands out even more. The soundtrack, meanwhile, matches perfectly with every scene being presented. Its use of Piano and strings creates a rather vivid feeling for the setting as well. The acting was done rather well, they were able to voice the characters fluently withoutproblems.


  The story however, although not bad, wasn't all that perfect. Its flaws are mostly is attributed to the characters of the show. Now, they're not bad, in fact I rather liked the majority of them. At their best, they were funny and interesting. The interactions they have, although a bit unnatural at times, still felt rather genuine in others. At their worst, however, they tend to be bland, confusing, and forgettable. There are some characters that get thrown under the rug once their role was done. It made their existence rather meaningless since they were only shown for exposition or to create unneeded tension. 


  The bright side though, the story itself was able to hold its own as it went by, for the most part. The mixture of real and supernatural elements was done well here. It's relevance to both the setting and characters was the concept's greatest strength. The show's other strength lies with its tone, being able to tie in humor and drama perfectly without them interfering with one another. Even though the drama can be forced in some parts, it's few and far between.


  Overall, I really enjoyed this anime. Although not perfect, the story and characters were really well written. The production value was what made it better. So, I recommend you check it out when you can.

It takes a lot of talent to make a pure slice of life interesting. In order for it to have a unique feeling, the characters and their interactions have to be compelling, while the dialogues need something to keep us wanting more; that's the trickiest part, it can be done in multiple ways but is at the same time hard to get right. The conversations can be humorous, dramatic or just intelligent but they have to offer something to the audience. Does Kanon (from this point on I'm going to refer to it by title only, I always mean the 2006 version) capture manage topull this off?

In my opinion, it doesn't. Luckily, it really isn't a slice of life.


Admittedly, in the beginning it is, which is exactly why I find the first 6 or 7 episodes to be rather underwhelming. I get that there are several characters that must be developed and there are events to build up to but there's far too much padding and mindless cute banter for me not to fall asleep. The same could be accomplished in two or three episodes with little missing. It is a prime example of what many people think when they think "slice of life": it's cutesy, pretty stupid and annoying. This part I didn't like, even if I do understand the writers needing it to set up mysteries and introduce us to the cast. It didn't help that half of the plot relies on amnesia, which befalls like three out of six main characters; the anime was even honest to enough to straight up comment on that.


However, the rest of Kanon is by no means like that. It gets dramatic quickly and never drops the ball, resulting in a complete and touching story. Even though the series is arc-based, the parts are tightly connected and almost all come down to the lead's past, which is the main intrigue, as expected with amnesia as a main plot device. One of the arcs doesn't, really, it seems to be an issue the writers just wanted to comment on, possibly a tribute. It could be written out easily but is still identifiable and intense enough, so I didn't mind it. Speaking of amnesia, surprisingly there are good explanations for each character having it, not just for the sake of moving the plot, like this plot device is often utilized. Kudos to the writers on that one. 


Overall, the anime is very well-written once the story actually gets going. So much so that, while with 3 out of 5 main girls magic is directly involved in their subplots, there is never too much of it, just enough to justify the situation. It is used only as a means to make all this possible, and there is no explanation whatsoever but it is kept promptly out of focus and doesn't feel as a cheap writer's tool, just as a starting point for the plot. It's done in a pretty clever fashion, for example, at one point the show features a demon fighter, and, although the entities are real, they are invisible, so they feel more as a symbol of a threat than actual demonic beings. There is a surprising amount of symbolism later on, practically on the subject of dreams and acceptance, all well-handled. 


The characters are, in fact, not all that important here. The lead, Yuuichi, is a pretty boring "good guy", even though he has an interesting past. Most of the girls he interacts with don't have that much of a personality either, just a trait or two to make them stand out. Some are pretty unique, especially Mai; Shiori's case has been seen countless times but is interesting because of the angle they have decided to take. Others are mostly your typical "cute anime girls". The only thing that's important about them and what makes them so different is their relation to Yuuichi's past. So, we have a unique case here: a slice of life which, in fact, isn't character-driven. Which is why it doesn't work that well in the beginning.


The art certainly doesn't help the characters stand out. Kyoto Animation is often criticized for making everyone look the same, and while I normally don't agree (say what you want about Haruhi but it's definitely not the case there), it is sadly true here. All the female characters look the same; the only two things that differ are hair and eye color. I'm also not a big fan of the eyes that take up half the face. So, the job of making the characters memorable falls on the voice actors, who, thankfully, were up to the task. With this kind of animation, they are responsible for conveying the personalities, and they do a good job. None sound generic, I never had trouble telling one voice from the other.


Overall, I'd say Kanon has a great and compelling story, everyone's problems seem surprisingly real despite supernatural constantly being mentioned. The characters, if generic, are identifiable, partially because they fall under the "Every man" category because of it. For me, the show was held back by its slow start and art style but I still enjoyed the hell out of it. Easily an eight out of ten, nine if you don't mind this kind of animation.

Okay just to confirm things, based on the main picture this is not a harem. The story started out with the main character slowly gaining pieces of his memory back. Most of the people he met were connected to his childhood. The story was pretty much interesting.

Part two of the Key/KyoAni collaborated trilogy continues their moe fan service that drives many male otaku insane for some reason and the emotional rollercoaster anime, only this time there is a few changes from the last series. For one, it’s longer than 12 episodes and while it may not be as different from the other Key/KyoAni shows, it’s……something that going to be explained once we get into the review.
Teen-aged Yuichi used to visit his aunt and cousin Nayuki all the time as a kid, but it has been seven years and his memory of that time has faded. Now he has come to livewith them to finish out his high school career beginning with the winter semester, and winds up in his cousin's class. During his first few days in town he (literally) runs into Ayu, a small girl with a winged backpack that, after some prompting, he eventually remembers he used to know, and starts hanging out with her. An encounter with an amnesiac girl named Makoto, who can only remember that she has a grudge against Yuichi, results in Makoto coming to live at his aunt's house, and he also meets an assortment of other girls, including Nayuki's friend and classmate Kaori, the mysteriously truant Shiori, and upperclassmen Sayuri and Mai. As pleasant as things are, though, mysteries abound. What happened to Makoto's memory? Why can't he remember more? And what other secrets lurk in this town?


OK, I got to know, most of the time so many things happen in this show with so many storylines, often end quickly (very quickly) or get back seated until the end of the series but other than that, there was a change of pace in this type of show. Usually, one of the female characters suffer from amnesia, not knowing their past and it gets retreaded throughout but this time, the main male character Yuichi is the one to have that. I don’t know what other Key/KyoAni show does that but it’s something fresh. It also has that formula to really make you either sad or it wants you to cry (very hard) when you hear the side stories of someone that got sick from……..well, something (They will never mention what sickness they got. Possibly the convenience sickness) and/or some other very tragic heartbreaking story and most of the time, I was immersed in some of those parts but mostly the lighter side of the anime; the antics that makes it seem less overly dramatic but genuinely funny.


Speaking of being genuinely funny, the main character Yuichi is actually one of my favorite characters on the show; he’s the type of guy that can work his sarcasm in being funny without trying to, can be jokey without being a douchebag, and also someone I gave a damn about, but unfortunately I can say the less for the female characters or the half-harem section of the characters. They aren’t very strong character types with the standards of it being the sweet one, sickly one, H.M.G.I.C. (Head Moe Girl in Charge), tsundere, etc. it’s your basic anime traits in female characters just like in the last entry, only they’re slightly noticeable.


The animation is a better effort from Kyoto Animation here than in Air, as it did felt livelier and very vibrant. The character designs are still the same as their other Key efforts with the big-eyed moe girls and the older characters looking the same age as the girls and even the main girl Ayu appears to be a small child but she’s actually 17. Yeah, I’ll say they don’t want to age their characters when they should have. The music is pure Key signature, meaning that it does sound like it’s from a visual novel and yes, I know this is based on a visual novel but I wish it didn’t always sound like that. I thought of the opening theme as soft and quiet building up every time it plays and it matches the tone of the show to a tee.


I watched the English dub of this by ADV Films (although FUNimation took over N.A. distribution rights) and while people say that it isn’t very moe like the Japanese version, it’s actually subjective to say that. I would’ve been annoyed if I watched it in the Japanese as I’m glad that the English dub didn’t try to go that route (plus, the actresses did sound annoyingly cute in their own way). Noted performances include Chris Patton as Yuichi, a relatively then-unknown Britney Karbowski as Ayu, and Jessica Boone as Nayuki.


FINAL VERDICT: Honestly, after watching this, I prefer this show to Air in terms of them being actually longer so the story didn’t go too fast, but I did felt like I gotten lost watching some of the episodes in plot and the sappiness and sadness were played in for dramatics. Like Air, I would say you should stream before you even think of buying the show.

Writing an early review, only on episode 9 right now, having a hard time deciding whether to finish this show.  Although I think this show has some great humor the arc it's progressing through really seems poor and much of what goes on I find very annoying.  Although I like most of the characters, mikoto is one that I went from accepting as a normal addition to pissing me off.  I really don't think the show connects well between it's supernatural element and the reaction of it's characters.  Now, that's kinda hard to put out since I can't really force howsomeone would react to the supernatural, but even in a genre that deals with escape from reality, this show is quite aggravating in a way I don't usually have to deal with. A very touching anime which is put together magnificently whether it be the way that each of the characters are developed or each of the unique stories which the characters hold.
Story: 8/10
This story like many other key titles tends to send your heart on a journey in which some moments you will be left laughing and at other times to the point where tears start to roll down your face.
It splits each girl's story into arc's in which Yuichi has to help them tackle the problem that they face. This may seem like a simple and quite cliche'd concept but  they conduct it beautifullyto make you feel as if you were there, so when they want you to be sad you will and when they want you to be happy you will as well.  Each girls story don't feel similar and each one unravels in a different way which keeps the anime refreshing. However like I find in a lot of key anime's, they tend to discard characters once there arc is done.


Art: 8/10


What can I say about the art of Kanon? Well it is gorgeous with a varieties of colors which are used well to set the mood of what's happening currently in the anime. The characters are all well designed and although they may not appeal to all I personally liked the way in which they were designed. Although it was quite reminiscent of some other key titles.


Sound: 9/10


I find that sound in these types of anime is always very important to the way in which you feel. Kanon hits it bang on with the way that they wish to make you feel. I never found that there was a song that was distinctively out of place with the scene. The voice acting of each characters was quite distinct and crisp so you don't mix up them, overall this was quite a big aspect for me about the anime.


Character: 8/10


Even though I felt initially that the characters were quite samey to others I'd seen before the way in which they unveiled there back stories made them seem different. Yuichi was a really good character, he's quite unique for a lead as there is almost two sides of his character. At some times he'll be quite jokey and funny, but when things get serious he fits that role perfectly as well. The beauty of the characters is that there mystery that is continuously presented is what really the driving force of you wanting to keep going onto the next episode.


Enjoyment: 8/10


I enjoyed this anime a lot.The way they blended each aspect they were going for whether it be the supernatural side of things or the slice of life side made it overall quite an enjoyable experience that I would recommend for others to watch.


Overall, it may not be every bodies cup of tea but personally I found it quite a dazzling anime so 8/10

Predictable to the very end. Cliche and annoying characters, bland music and character design, but beautiful art. 6/10.
If it weren't for the characters annoying catchphrases, Uguu, Auu, fighto-dayo, I would've liked the show more.

I tried by best to avoid spoilers.
Story - 
Kanon is a slice of life anime, set in a wintery town. The overall anime appears to take place during winter and ending with the melting of the snow into spring. The story itself also bears a faint resemblance to a musical Canon... where each of the notes (Characters sub plots) come together and harmonise. The main character is recovering the memories of his child hood  and he has returned to the snowy village. The story is funny at times, it had me in stitches and some of the on going gags are pure genius. 
Howeverthis slice of life breaks to reveal a down tempo, the plot develops into an emotional kicker.At times I was close to dropping the anime because it because very very depressing. However I stuck with it and like a true canon it came together and really provides a shocking ending. The plot is carefully written and every character is loveable in their own way. Each shine through the plot.\n
The plot gets full marks from me as I feel it developed nicely and was very cleverly written.\n\n
Art and sound- \n
Art wise there is some nice settings and the town becomes very familiar throughout. The sound for the anime is nice our opening theme plays and develops throughout, Pachibel's canon in D is also played through out as well as some more classical tunes. The music fits nicely as they all develop and harmonise. The pieces are mainly in minor however our opening theme and the canon are written in major, Signalling that our sad plot is dotted with hope. \n\n
Character - \n
Each character has their own personality which sparkles and each has a well developed back story. I at first disliked a few characters however by the end I loved them all. They grow on you through the very well written plot. The plot develops as one by one the back stories and explanations on each character is given.\n
You will love the array of personalties gained.\n\n
Enjoyment and Overall - \n
Overall this anime is certainly one I would recommend, If you are a lover of slice of life this is an anime for you. Also music lovers may gain some pleasure from this anime due to its mirror of the canon. Anyone looking for a good laugh will fall for Kanon's humour and wit.

It's like a rollercoaster of emotions when it comes to this anime. I literally was shocked and had "dust" in my eye when watching it... Kinda makes me seem girly but... I dont care it was that good!

I'll be honest, at first, I thought Kanon was going to be the exact same thing as Clannad.  A troubled teenage boy helping a group of troubled teenage girls to overcome their problems and, at the same time, he learns how to overcome his.  Though, Key really pulled something off with both of these shows.  Sure they both begin the same way.  A cryptic monologue that is explained at the end of the story, an unintentionally-rude, teenage boy who helps about five teenage, girls.  They even have the mutual aspect of having at least one of the main, female charactersand the main, male character meet as children and part ways because of tragic accident (Kotomi and Tomoya; Yuichi and Ayu).  Though, don't let these similarities fool you.  Kanon's storyline travels down a completely different route, compared to Clannad.  One that is both unique and meaningful.  The dramatic dialogue isn't cheesy, there are some "slice of life" lessons worth holding onto, powerful symbolism, and a little bit of fantastic mystery (or mysterious fantasy, if it helps).


I did notice that, sometimes, when mystery and fantasy are tied together, the story becomes hard follow (Clannad is the perfect example).  Though, don't worry, the story is cleared up, nicely.  You won't have to search for a forum that explains what actually happened at the end.  


Just let the progress and you will see that this anime was shockingly, well written.
